user_review: As ongoing COVID-19 pandemic continues to affect businesses, it has forced many of us to think differently about what constitutes a disaster.  Many business owners are changing their mission statement to succeed and to embrace positive disruptions.  I came across Europea on René Levesque et de la Montagne, a strategic location in the heart of downtown Montreal.  What used to be just a fancy and prestigious restaurant has now expanded, in addition to takeout and delivery, to a very appealing showroom full of colourful delights.  What a pleasure to see all these delicious "mini bouchées", nicely laid out on the shelves.  Atmosphere was warm and we were greeted with cookies to taste, hot off the oven.  With our purchases, we were offered tokens that you can use to select fancy mini boxes of cookies through a machine dispenser.  What a great way to make a powerful statement.  A remarkable  visionary and an exemplary way to revolutionize the culinary industry.

This was such an amazing restaurant in terms of experience and food from the beginning to the end of the meal. The lobster bisque, calamari, and steak were great. All of the courses were pretty good. The way the food was presented was quirky which I liked. The dessert came with cotton candy and candy bags hanging from a tree which was cute. I would definitely come back here when visiting Montreal again.

Wow!  I finally got the chance to dine at this fabulous restaurant and loved loved it!!  I had the privelge of being invited to a special 8 course menu for 75$  and it was worthy every penny.  Dinning at this Top MTL resto is really a foodie's dream come true!  Their new location located on rue de la montagne is super modern and very classy!  They have a gorgeous open kitchen and you can easily watch the Master Chef at work!  Foodwise-absolutely delicious and unique.This is no ordinary service. Think of it as a theatrical dining experience - beautifully plated dishes all packed with unique delicious flavors and excellent service.  Yes I was lucky enough to be invited to a reduced price menu but I would have paid the full price of 125$ per person as it is so worth it!. I definately recommend to try this out at least once if you can!  It's definately a TOP  foodie dining experience. Tried their famous lobster capuccino and wow! Everything we had was amazing!  We also got the chance to meet and take picture with Chef Jerome Ferrer!  Such a down to earth fellow!  If one day I win the lottery I'll be dining here on a monthly basis!  Lol

We came for my birthday dinner. We reserved at 8pm. Arrived at 8 and waited in the lounge. We got seated at 9 pm. it's the MTL a table event. So I am guessing waiting one hour is not a regular routine? I never had a dinner this late. Thank God I ate some snack after work or I would be hungry to death. The whole experience was full of surprises. For us finishing dinner at 11:30 pm was a very exhausting experience,especially on a weekday. At the end we were yawning a lot. But still we were so satisfied with food. The menu said 7 courses(83$), but we only received six beforehand we inserted card to the machine. Then I asked about the 7th course. The last dish was a bag of take-home candy. I don't want to describe all the dishes to spoil the surprises for you. In a nut shell, I like all the dishes. Only the oyster was a bit fishy. It's my fifth time with Europea but first time to try this new location. I really need to verify the usual waiting time and be prepared. The surprises and fanciness were upgraded for sure, just the waiting time was abnormal for us.

If you are a fan of perfectly executed multi-course meals, complete with gimmicks and little magic tricks, then this is the place for you. Dining is part of the experience, but certainly not the reason you go here. You go here for a nearly 3 hour meal/show put on by the dedicated waitstaff and sommeliers. There are a lot of elements to the meal with separate ornate services of food and beverage, each with their own separate presentations. Make no mistake about it. You will be dinged REALLY hard in the pocketbook here. They will push the wine pairing option until you feel foolish saying no. There are two options at 75$/person or 150$/person. Both options will get you 4 small pours of various wines/bubbly. My wife and I took the 75$ option, therefore spending 150$ on wine. Adding the 4 mini pours of wine together, I doubt the total exceeds one standard bottle of wine... maybe by a fraction, but no more. Obviously, we should have just ordered a regular bottle of wine and saved ourselves a bunch of money. That said, we fell prey to the dog and pony show which is undoubtedly essential to the restaurant's ability to pay rent on the same block as the Bell Centre. While I believe you can go a la carte, most people choose one of 2 tasting menus. I think ours was the more moderately priced one at 95$/person. The evening starts by having the guests seated in the lounge. It strongly appears that this is their policy whether or not the table is ready. They want you ordering a cocktail, and who wouldn't when the price of said beverage hovers around the 20$ mark. They give you some dried vegetable chips or something akin to that. Magically, after the cocktail is ordered, they announce that the table is ready. (Pssst....hey guys, I would have ordered a drink anyways)The meal starts with some sort of fake tree spewing dry ice. I still don't understand why. Something about a towel to wipe my hands? The tree branches hold two pieces of baked goods that you dip in an off beige sauce. It was pretty tasty.Then comes an amuse bouche of dried fish and some sort of beef balls. Again pretty tasty.Out comes another box with another towel and a note from the chef.Next up, you've got a lobster cappuccino. Basically it's glorified clam chowder with a piece of lobster at the bottom. Two sips and you're done.They do serve delicious croissants and bread with butter which we filled up on. Don't ask me what a croissant is doing at a dinner service, but who am I to argue with a breakfast treat this well prepared?My wife had some sort of lobster tisane and dish that included a broth prepared in a bubbling multi-layered glass science experiment, the type you didn't understand properly in high school, because...who cares. It tasted weird according to m'lady.I had some foie gras which was decent and served in 3 variationsThen comes the oyster show. They invite you to put on these goggles and watch a video of an oyster fisherman. Ok...I'll bite. When the video is over, you have a dish of salt water with inedible brown rocks (don't mistake these or you will be visiting the dentist), and ONE oyster. Yeah, they put some stuff in the oyster, but guess what...it tasted like an oyster. Maybe across the street at Old Orchard, they can show you a video of a chicken farm and then present you with a single chicken wing. For our mains, my wife had this intricate fish dish, while I had the beef which was essentially 3 ounces of filet, about a tablespoon of tartare (served on a giant rock), and literally a single TEASPOON of braised brisket that had undergone some mythical and magical treatment earlier in the afternoon (i.e. they cooked it) At this point, they give you a piece of white paper and a paintbrush with water to dip. They tell you to paint. Essentially, another note from the chef is revealed. They are basically telling you that a roasted marshmallow in forthcoming. Each diner gets one marshmallow to cook over a gas flame. It was good. The part I really liked was the chocolate and cream filled cigar which accompanied the dessert.They finish the meal with a mountain of maple cotton candy and a clay pot that you smash with an actual hammer to get to some honeycomb toffee chunks like the inside of a Crunchy bar. Together with the cotton candy, I really think they must have a side deal with a dental clinic. What am I, 11 years old? For the fifth dessert, they serve some sort of pretty plated arrangement which i think tasted like blueberry. As a nice touch, when you are paying the bill, they give you a loaf of orange bread "for breakfast tomorrow" in a Jerome Ferrer bag. A couple of tasting menus, 2 ill advised wine pairings, and a couple of cocktails. Tax and tip.....over 500$. The orange loaf the next morning was great. Also, we did have fun throughout. Ultimately, however, this place is overpriced, touristy, and the type of thing that I really only need to do once in my life, if that.

Came here for a lunch meeting and let me tell you it's way to overpriced and over rated.... Service is horrible! Finally cought the waiters attention after 10min to Ask for some sparkling water we got it 5 min later and we were ready to order and wanted a quick bite to eat It took us like 25-35 min wait to get just our water and over an hour for a tiny little salad with barely anything in it. -.- the worst part is the waiter came to refill the sparkling water by adding tap water .... nooooo you don't do that.... I expressed to him that it was a big no no to mix sparkling and tap in the same glass and if he wanted to bring tap water he had to bring separate glasses he didn't care and repeated the same offence twice. I was furious! Food: it was pretty good ! Sea bass was amazing and tender .. I really enjoyed it and the salad was fresh but a bit overpriced for its portionHowever the service is very important and it was horrible and dreadfully long ! I decided not to tip as the waiter really didn't care whatsoever. He was mad that we didn't tip.. I'm like you want a tip? I'll give you a tip .... Be more friendly to your customers and actually act like you care maybe it'll change the outcome of the way people tip!

We went with the special of the night for 125 CAD and did not regret it. With only a weekend to spare in Montreal, we decided that a 3.5 hour meal with Jerome Ferrer would be the best way to spend an evening.The experience was immersive, involving touch, smell, and sight - highlights were:- the smell of active charcoal burning under our lobster tails, evoking beachside grilling- taking a fishing trip with Jerome Ferrer with Oculus goggles paired with an oyster dish- a chocolate rolled cigar and a shot of whiskey infused chocolate- the whimsical colors of a maple-flavored cotton candy tree and gin cocktail (as the server shakes up your cocktails, you listen to bongo drum beats)- the lobster cappuccino (his signature!)- a delicate white fish steamed on a bed of citrus fruits and paired with an egg-based tarragon sauvignon sauceJerome Ferrer and his team of chefs and servers deliver a dining experience that engages all five of your senses - recommend if you're looking for something memorable, different, and of course, delicious.

As ever, the food and service at Europea was amazing. I started with a Maryland crab-cake  that was almost as satisfying as Baltimore's finest. The flavour and texture of the lump crabmeat was so rewarding after years of having eaten crab-flavoured sawdust at so many other restaurants. My friend's squash soup was both pretty and tasty.We both then chose the Lamb shoulder confit - a perfect cylinder of fragrant lamb bathed in a flavourful brown gravy and surrounded by tender white salsify. Atop the lamb - a  puree of (orange) peppers which had the perfect intensity to balance the savouriness of the lamb.During the meal we were offered yummy buttery croissants and other breads. All were delicious but the butteriness of the croissants had us searching for a napkin - none of which were to be found. We eyed the fabric sofas upon which we were seated but opted to keep it classy. If there was a perfect time to have a pocket square at the ready it would have been then; instead we dined with buttery fingers.Desert was the perfect culmination of this wonderful luncheon. We both had their cheesecake then nibbled on the assorted little pastries. Europea's lunch menu is online; bookmark it.

My girlfriend took me here for my birthday dinner on a long weekend trip to Montréal. Let's just say, our experience was so amazing that we would do a day trip (from Buffalo) to eat here.If I could leave 6 stars I would. Jérôme Ferrer was one of the best meals I've experienced in my lifetime. We went with the 12 course Experience. Definitely worth the price! When signing up for this option, you are signing up for not only for superb food but a superb performance. Our experience started with enjoying two martinis along with complimentary truffle Parmesan popcorn in the lounge area. From there, our bartender walked us to our table where our experience began. Our 12 courses also included an interactive VR journey to where our oysters were caught, along with an audio musical soundtrack to the presentation of one of dessert courses. The server was completely unbelievable, even gifting me one of the chefs cookbooks as a birthday gift.What really put our meal over the top was upon looking into the open kitchen. One of the servers noticed me and my girlfriend intrigued with the kitchen. He insisted on giving us a tour, allowing us to even shake hands with the chef. This has never happened to us and really left us with an unforgettable experience. This restaurant made you feel special. Between meeting the chef, eating the superb food, watching the show that came with each course, and the amazing hospitality, it will leave you wanting more, even after sitting down for a 3.5 hour meal. We will definitely be back soon and look forward to doing it all over again.

We came to Europea to celebrate my bf's birthday. The experience of the set menu was very different and we both really enjoyed it. The food, especially the main (beef 3 ways), was very good and the service was delightful. Highly recommend anyone (even vegans) to come try this restaurant.

It's always been one of my favorite restaurant , always have new ideas and good food . But before move , it used to have individual orders , now there is only tasting menu , I hope could keep at least some individual orders for more options . 2nd , now the valet parking is super hard , de la montagne is a very busy street so if you flash and park there is quiet impossible to make a such thing . You will block the street and Ppl behind your card . Should find some other place or just give the client place where your valet are and when client finishes meal give a pass to garb . I think it will be better

Is it worth it? Yes!I brought my mom to Europea back in October for their anniversary six-course meal. Not to spoil, with all the surprises, it was more like a nine-course meal!!!As for the food, everything was amazing and sort of... whimsical! It is definitely an experience you gotta try once! Like they say, you eat with the eyes. I won't give too much details as the food tastes just so yummy when you're surprised (PS. I have attached photos with no description for those who have a need to know what they are eating prior).The service was impeccable and courteous. The handwritten note by the chef was a really nice touch!TIP. I know it's hard but TRY not to look at the other table. Be delighted by the surprises. Enjoy!Oh and did I mention pre-dessert? :P

(Vegetarian Review)As I'm on a personal mission to try every vegetarian tasting menu, I had to stop by Europea when I was in Montreal. We made reservations as a group of 6 and were seated promptly. I thought the meal was reasonably priced (especially compared to SF / NY) for a tasting menu, and there was more than enough food for everyone.Pros(+) Interesting displays: Everything was very unique at the restaurant including the cotton candy tree and goat cheese lollipops. It was definitely a fun experience for the group(+) Vegetarian option: I appreciated having a vegetarian option, and I saw that there was a vegan tasting on the menu as well(+) Relatively inexpensive compared to other tastings(+) Great service ***We also ran into the Europea Mobile food truck the next day which was also good and has more fast-food-esque options. Would recommend trying both!

+.5 for serviceNumber 1 restaurant in Canada. Number 24 restaurant in the world (or something like that). A final bill for 5 that's equivalent to a week's paycheque for many people. That's basically Europea in a nutshell.I was one of the first people to try their new location, which was a lot closer to the central station. The place was extremely open concept with high ceilings. I don't want to explain/spoil too much about the restaurant concept, but there's uniqueness throughout that make the price you pay worth it.Some highlights included the lobster tea, "sea bed myths and legends", "bounty of the land", and the 3-course dessert. I don't wanna explain too much more of what they really are as it will ruin the surprise, but definitely consider ordering items that have any lobster (tea, cappuccino, or bisque) or calamari.I did take away 1 star for how the restaurant is laid out. If you end up getting a corner table (far right area on the main floor), you will have a lack of lighting. Unfortunately my group did get that table, and the lighting paled compared to other sections of the restaurant.Service is tremendous. Like, really tremendous. Probably one of the best services I've ever had in a restaurant, especially given its high standing. I'm not one to judge whether the "#1 restaurant in Canada" claim holds water, but I'm confident in saying it's up there in "expensive restaurants that I would recommend everyone to try once".

Great experience here for a birthday dinner during a long weekend in Montreal. My boyfriend and I both got the signature tasting menu, which was a steal for $130 CAD. There are 10 courses listed, but we also received several amuse bouches (I think at least 4) and an extra dessert .Presentation of everything was fantastic, as many others have noted. I loved how many of the dishes were slightly interactive, such as having to smash open the clay pot that the veal was braised in or having a smoked salmon amuse literally being served inside smoke.Service was also lovely, a stark contrast to another dinner that we'd had a few nights prior. However, will note that the pacing of the meal was quite leisurely (think our dinner took over 3 hours - I've had 20 course meals take that long), so don't come here if you're in a rush.Only ding is that I wish some of the flavor and preparation of the dishes was able to match the high caliber of presentation. While everything was impeccably prepared, the actual taste of a majority of the dishes just didn't have that same wow factor. Also - must try the sortilege cocktail! It was so yummy, and came with a piece of maple candy that slowly melted as you sipped on the drink as well.

We came here as a large group for a corporate dinner and everyone loved it. The decor is elegant yet cozy and not pretentious, the staff is extremely professional and accommodating, each of them was so friendly from the moment they greeted us at the door to when we left , very strong customer service. The prices here are not cheap but you are paying for the whole experience and a very unique meal prepared with skill detail and care. Definitely a special occasion restaurant but you will have a very unique and delicious dining experience. We had a multi course tasting menu surf & Turf , including oysters , crab claw and crab cake , steak , beef tartare , lobster cappucino, amazing bread selection , dessert and more. Each course was beautifully presented and was so flavourful and unique. The steak was so tasty and juicy and the crab cake was so fresh and full of flavour as well (definitely two of my favourites , as well as the lobster cappuccino). Tip , don't skip the bread when they come around with the basket, it was phenomenal (just try it you'll see !). The desserts were whimsical and fun , we had cotton candy , cinnamon beignet, and a really fun chocolate cigar that looked so real that when I showed people the photo they couldn't believe it was made of chocolate and cream filling. We also got to go to the kitchen and meet the chef which was fun, he was so friendly and welcoming and the kitchen was spotless and ran so smoothly , you can see how attentive they are on the details. Hands down one of the best restaurants in montreal.

This review is for the lunchboxes, and not the restaurant, which is next door. You can get lunchboxes to go from predetermined dishes throughout the week. I had a club sandwich and poutine.The good: The food is terrific! The choices of plates and nice and fancy (even their poutine was fancy). The boxes comes with utensils and napkins. Boxes also comes with a small desert. Felt full all day (even skipped dinner because l was too full). The bad: lt is pricey. Desert was dry and tasteless. Can be confused between lunchbox and restaurant doors. You can wait a while for your meal to be ready.In the end, if you have $20 to spend on a lunch, this is a strong suggestion.

Amazing dinner! I was late as I thought my dinner was at 830 but it was 7, yikes. They accommodate me. I picked the surf and turf 7 course meal dinner special and it was amazing! Try it and experience the service, food and beverages.

EUROPEA was my favorite French restaurant in Montreal. I used to go there a lot when they were in the old location, and I really liked the dishes they used to have. The fois gras, the lobster cappuccino, the steak, the cheese lollipop, the scallop risotto.... They were so special and tasty.However, I went to the new location for lunch a couple days ago, it really disappointed me. The price went down, the quality of dishes went down as well.We had fois gras, scallops and braised beef. The fois gras wasn't as good as the old one, the scallop was tasteless, the braised beef was horrible, which was dry, boring and I couldn't even finish. I asked the waiter why they changed the lunch menu, he told me that some customers told them: former lunch dishes take a lot of time to wait, so they make something faster now. I understand that, but I don't think 35 dollars for dishes like that is worth. I'd rather spend more money and more time to have a decent dish, not something cheap like a group meal (especially the braised beef).Also, the service wasn't as warm as before, there were just a few waiters there, sometimes you can't even get the attention from them.I know my comment can't changed anything, but I hope the restaurant could consider my advise. PLEASE DON'T MAKE CHEAP DISHES like that, people go there don't mind to spending extra 25 dollars or even more dollars for something decent. Btw, I didn't try the dinner menu, hope they're better than lunch.

I had high hopes going in to Europea for a group dinner based on other reviews but was overall disappointed with the evening. The highlight of the restaurant is the service, which is 5 star all the way.  Attentive, friendly, warm and personal.  I found the decor to be a bit tired and in need of a refresh.  It looked like cutting edge resto decor from the late 1990s. The food, with a few exceptions, was just ok.  Multiple appetizers, most of which I found quite bland, except for the lobster cappuccino which was delicious, and the calamari, which was also excellent.  I had the halibut as my main which I also found lacked flavour and was overwhelmed by an overly sweet coconut sauce.  The presentation of the dishes would have been cutting edge about 10 years ago but felt tired to me. Unfortunately I didn't get to stay for dessert as I got called into work.  My friends who stayed did rave about them, so perhaps I would have given this a four star if I'd had the chance to try them. Overall it wasn't bad, but for the price point I think there are more exciting tasting menus in Montreal right now for the same money.

This has been a restaurant I've been wanting to go for the longest time and all the rumours I heard didn't disappoint! This was one of the most delicious meals I've ever had. A++ for presentation,align with A++ for the different flavours in each dish! I took the signature menu of 10 courses. They might be small dishes but you appreciate the taste so much more! And by the end of 10 dishes I couldn't eat anymore! The service is EXCELLENT. The place was bigger than I thought looking from the outside. This is one place everyone should go too at least once,not just for the food but for the experience!!

What a fun and unique experience! I went with a group of about ten people and we had the 11(?)-course dinner. It was such an adventure. The food was fantastic. I ate an oyster for the first time and actually liked it.The staff was very accommodating and even made a vegetarian version for a member of our party.For those complaining it is slow... of course it is. That's part of the point! Sit back and enjoy!

So we took a Groupon for 2 for lunch.And we had a memorable delicious extravagant and fancy lunch! We had a five-course meal. We paid around 145$ including service and taxes and boy, every bit of it was worth it.Elliot - Our server was a delightful, kind and impressive person.The kind of service and attention to details were spectacular! The food prep and serving was beautiful. Reservations:I took the vegetarian/vegan meal and my hubby chose white meat diet. They take these details while you call for booking and then they call you back to reconfirm your reservations.Food: They shared the pre-fix menu choices for lunch and for me they mentioned all that they have. and then they started to serve. wow! Not only the presentation of the food was unique but the food as well. We started goat cheese and pesto lollipops & popcorns and a choice of wine, the bottled to be shared between two of us and left over was given to take home. We chose white wine and we got again a delicious French wine (Chartier), which is like 20$ in LCBO and then we were served taro/oregano- truffled cappuccino & shrimp cappuccino(Hubby). The side of bread (we had choices) with 3 kinds of butter, I loved the flower butter. The bread was freshly baked and aromatic.Now for the mains, I had Quash/cashew Patty along with a fried roll. So yum! so so so yum! It was smoked and garnished with red quinoa. My hubby chose Foi Gras, he got it along with mushroom shaped breads served in a book box, a fried roll and a smoothie(I wish I was served too). the smoothie was beet/green apple and was delicious. For second mains, I had roots with hummus- delicious, roots were steamed to perfection, to compliment they had served the side of sweet quinoa and salty sauteed mushrooms.Oh so yum! My hubby had some Bass, which was first smoked in the grass and was shown to him for his approval to serve. Now the dessert:Some berry mouse with sorbet- oh so delicious so perfectly sweetened, along with blueberry cotton candy tree and Meringue to share. Then we got a choice of coffee and tea. they served Nespresso coffee along with Tea cakes (In a to-go box, so that you can take the leftovers). Well, It's not over yet.We also received an autograph from the chef, a jar of eggplant caviar, a big Meringue to take home along with tea cakes and wine. It was a memorable and delicious experience! Loved it! Would definitely go back!

My rating will be 3Es :)Excellent food presentationExcellent food qualityExcellent serviceWent there for my wedding anniversary and wow am I pleased to chose them for the occasion.Europea offer great variety of fine French cuisine, the presentation is stunning. Let's just say... It's so beautiful that you don't want to eat it lol.Food quality is amazing, very tasty and they setup the course accordingly to ensure you enjoy every dish to the maximum.Service: every single dish they put on your table, they will explain what it is, how it's made and how to taste it. They take extra care to details so much they have a wine expert to help us choose the wine to match with the meal.You will not be disappointed, highly recommended

Multimedia food experience with clumsy service.Above all this is a multimedia food experience that can leave a few of us a little baffled but I definitely had fun.  I thought the food was spectacular, great ingredients, delicate and subtle.  Presentation was also impeccable.  The 12 service is a little heavy on seafood/fish/shellfish but excellent nonetheless.  We went for the prestige wine pairing and although the wines were delicious most of them were Bourgogne wines - there's room for improvement there.The bad: the service.  When you go to a place like this, you expect the best.  I thought the service was rough, gauche and poorly rehearsed.  When you try to mix multimedia with dishes, you gotta have a well timed execution and clearly they're just not there yet.  Dishes are late, explanations are late, "sensory" experiences left unexplained, etc.  The whole thing was a mess from start to finish.  I stopped counting the times the waiters bumped into the sofa and almost knocked over my glass.  Either fix the layout or get it together!

Very friendly service! I ordered the 7 courses, perfect portion for dinner. All the dishes are very creative, with VR screens and headphones. The wine paring was excellent. The desserts were a bit too much. Over all, good!

It's upscale, it's expensive but is it worth the hype? Short answer is yes, long answer is that it depends on your expectations. We had the menu de degustation and it was fantastic! The service is just impeccable and the food is what you would expect from an upscale French restaurant. A go-to place for a business meeting or a celebration. If the price isn't a problem, this place should definitely be on your go-to list. However if it's not, then it's not someplace that you will regret missing, there are many budget-friendlier restaurants out there just as good.

Where to start...This place is amazing. We came here for their 15th year anniversary and they had a special menu for 50$. For the experience, service and the food we had, the price was definitely worth it. The food is amazing. All the appetizers came in a very creative manner and it was very fun to eat them. The lobster cappucino was odd but absolutely delicious.The beef/duck tartare was probably one of the best tartare i've had so far. The dessert is so beautiful and there were so many we couldn't finish them all. The service is great. The staff is very friendly and welcoming. The place is fancy and the ambiance was great. I don't think it's possible to leave this place unhappy.

Was worried that those who wrote the bad reviews were right...and they were!Glad that my friend and I went for lunch instead of dinner as I would have been pissed paying so much more for just ok food.Choice of $60/5 course meal or $45/4 course meal...glad we did the $45 one as I thought it will wasn't worth the price.Started with the amuse bouche which were meh. Truffle oil drizzled popcorn didn't taste much better than the cheese popcorn I would get out of a bag bought at the supermarket...as a matter of fact, the popcorn was stale! Pesto lollipop...didn't like the combination. The only item that was decent in the amuse bouche was the beef jerky.Started with a lobster cappuccino...ok that was really fantastic...but you can really feel like they put in tons of butter. Anything with butter is good right?Entree was smoked duck with beef...nothing special. Presentation was nice but taste was ordinary. The shrimp cannoli was ok but again taste was not memorable.Main was scallop with asparagus risotto. Scallop lacked a bit of salt and the risotto was bland. The entire dish was actually bland. I ate the 2 scallops and a bit of the risotto. The bar was actually decent in taste but again could taste tons of butter in the sauce.Dessert consisted of a cotton candy tree, some meringue, madeleines, and some sort of strawberry mousse cake with a thick coat of sugar that you need to crack before getting to the bottom of the cup. I wished I didn't mixed in the hard top sugar because it was just too much and it got stuck in my teeth and didn't add anything to the dessert. I've seen tons of pictures on Yelp about the dishes and they have not changed a bit. I feel like the menu hasn't been changed in ages...really lacking creativity.I must agree with the lower reviews that pricing is steep and taste is forgettable! Decor isn't even that nice.Montreal has tons of great restaurants so spend your money elsewhere.It might have been a great restaurants a decade ago, but it has not evolved and lots of better choices now.

My experience wasn't good at this restaurant from the beginning, as we were sitting there over 20 min waiting for someone to come take our order and I felt like we were invisible or they totally forgot about us. Finally someone came after we complained but there was no apology at all. Food was ok but nothing special, it's all about presentation and performance. To make it worse, they charged $80 more for our drinks and thank god we noticed it before we paid. We questioned about it and they corrected the bill but it took another 15 min to correct and again, there was no apology at all. Overall it was such disappointing and unpleasant experience and I'll never go back or recommend this place to anyone.

I admit that this was the fanciest most expensive meal thus far of my 30 years. And NO regrets because it was exquisitely delicious!!!When you order the 6-course meal, you actually will be getting much more than that, since between those courses they give you about 6 other "treats."The courses with options I would recommend the calamari or foie gras. And I would recommend the veal, Cornish hen and the halibut sea bass which all tender, succulent/moist and flavorful. Really, there's no going wrong in the end.Oh and there's a lot of dessert at the end of the meal... so prepare for that!

Great service, good food. Fantastic wine selection. Went for lunch on a weekday.This is a lovely restaurant. I was a bit apprehensive since a lot of recent reviews seemed to be disappointed by the food but it turned out to be perfectly fine. It started with canapés of beef jerky, cheese sandwich lollipops, and truffle popcorn. All of them were lovely, but I thought the beef jerky was just meh. Tasted like good jerky but nothing other than that. The lobster bisque cappuccino delivers a strong flavor punch. I also liked the beef tartar and the squid tagliatelle . The veloute, foei gras, fish, risotto, and tenderloin were solid but lacked the wow factor. The desserts were all on the sweeter side.Overall, delivers strong on presentation. Solid on service and taste, depending on menu selection. Bread & butter was meh. Recommended.

Absolutely out of this world dining experience. Yes, eating here is an experience. The prices on the appetizers and entrees are steep, but that's because all orders include many small dishes throughout the meal. No need to get the fixed tasting menu, because whatever you end up ordering will essentially become a tasting menu.#treatyoself

Every year, if I am lucky, I encounter a restaurant that offers a truly memorable experience. Europea was that restaurant for me in 2016, so much so that I intend to omit some details of our experience so that it is a surprising treat for you, as well. I will leave you with this sentiment: the meal is an enchanting performance so sit back and take joy in it.I reserved well in advance, more than 8 weeks out, resulting in a lovely table by the window on the second floor overlooking the city street; during the summer, I would imagine that the area would come alive.As we reviewed the menu, we enjoyed a robust and tasty beef jerky, flavored popcorn, goat cheese lollipops, and herbed straws served in olive oil. They were an unexpected and delightful way to begin a meal filled with surprises. These little treats definitely set the right mood.In the end, we selected the 12-course tasting menu and were pleased with the decision. Note that a six-course table d'hôte and an à la carte menu are also available. Below are some of the items we enjoyed:- Arancini created to look like a truffle- Velvety lobster bisque with a cappuccino-like foam finish - so good I could have made a meal of it- Smoked lentil caviar in a crispy crust (a substitute for my salmon allergy)- Risotto with baby shrimp and beets- Calamari tagliatelle served with a quail egg and a creamy sauce, reminiscent of a carbonara - this was my sister's favorite- Pâté au torchon served with a tiny brioche- A well-prepared sea bass that was cooked in sweet hay and assorted citrus aromatics - this was my favorite- Cornish game hen cooked in breakable clay that was, unfortunately, a bit dry- Clever taste of braised beef layered with béarnaise and potatoes- A cheese tray that took into account our preferences, from a cellar of over 100 choices from Quebec- A wonderful assortment of sweet treats that begged for us to take home leftoversThroughout the 4-hour meal, the servers were energetic and playful. We thoroughly enjoyed the well-paced, thoughtfully-composed indulgences and appreciated how much the servers were very much a part of the overall experience. This meal has provided many lovely memories already so I encourage you to GO. Relish every moment of the experience.

So my actual score for Europea if possible would be 10/5 ;)This was the best food experience of my life and I am not basing that on the price (I have paid much more for sub-standard food and service).So starting with the reservations, relatively easy process requiring a credit card. I'd suggest booking at least a month in advance.I had the signature tasting menu for $129.50 which consists of 10 courses. With a seating time of 9 pm, I KID YOU NOT, my friend and I were there till 1 am. So when I say this was an experience, it was a 4 HOUR FOOD EXPERIENCE!I don't eat beef. So since 2 of the courses were veal, they were more than great about substituting those courses (and not with vegetables as is often done).We were served by two people the whole night. The male server was great. I forget his 3name (we were there in June) but he was hilarious and had a very dry sense of humour. ***Regarding the courses (NOTE: these are the listed courses on the menu - you get served additional items that are not on the menu):Amuse-Bouche - Lobster cream cappuccino with truffle purée - both my bff and I could have had a bucket of this eachAppetizer 1) Al dente lemony calamari tagliatelle - so many textures, every bite was divineAppetizer 2) Smoked deer tartar with thin cut french fries - this was the best dish of the night for me, the presentation was amazing, it came in glass casing filled with smoke which was uncovered with drama lol - who knew raw deer with tiny french fries could taste so amazing  - menu item was slow cooked Quebec veal carpaccio which my friend enjoyedAppetizer 3) Foie gras au torchon, crispy langoustine, home brioche - bite-sized items with amazing flavourMain Course 1) Macadamia nut crusted Halibut pave - this was the most delicate dish of the night - buttery soft fishPalate cleanser - Crispy-melting white cheese ice mist sorbetMain Course 2) Cornish hen breast cooked and scorched on maple wood chips - great presentation, they bring up a whole breast partly through the cooking process and describe the cooking method - this was my second substituted dish - the menu item is Quebec veal cheeks slowly braised and cooked in clay - they bring up the whole item as it's cooking and make you break the clay open before plating itThe Europea cheese cellar - you get to choose whatever cheeses you want or as we did it, the fromager asks about your tastes and brings what he thinks would suit your palette  Dessert 1) My passport to sweetness - cheesecake-like dessert revealed after the server melts the ball of white chocolate it's inDessert 2 and 3) Candy tree from Guilty land/Mignardises (mini cakes/cookies) - last 2 courses combined with a candy floss tree - we asked ours to be packed because we were literally bursting at the seams by this time***Observations:So it seems like bits of food when it comes out but we started having a hard time after finishing the halibut (after the first main course) and we are gals with healthy appetites lol. Put together, IT'S A LOT OF FOOD!! Trust me, arrive hungry.The presentations of the courses were each like a mini-show, so pay attention - one of the unlisted items (salmon in pastry) came in a wood box shaped like a book, server opened both at the same time and smoke blew into our faces in the best possible way lolService is the best I have ever had at any restaurant. The servers were friendly, attentive (every time you get up to go to the washroom they replace your place setting, as soon as you are done dish is cleared way), not pretentious etc.Very accommodating in terms of dietary restrictions. I was glad that they actually replaced the veal dishes with other meat dishes and not vegetables.Amazing French house wine for $8 a glass! The restaurant is rather romantic - we were the only non-couple there, other than 1 large group. Definitely a place to take a date.At the end, you get a huge meringue, wrapped up in a bag to take home with you.At the end of the night when we were done, as we were going down the stairs, I saw our server going down before us. When we reached the bottom, he was standing there with the door open for us (WHAT, WHO DOES THAT?!?) - Am I getting through the fact that the service was AHHHHMAZING!I did some research before picking this restaurant out of all the high-end restaurants available in Montreal, and I ended up picking this one as it had the most unique menu items, an extensive tasting menu that gave you a bit of everything, and the rave reviews on service.And as expected, it was a truly marvelous experience.

Dinner is a show here, and it's a good one. Style and service are top notch, but do outshine the flavor for the most part. The beginning (tuna tartare and calamari bowl) and end (cotton candy tree and white chocolate sphere) were much more interesting and delicious when matched up against the main proteins of halibut and beef.We did the signature menu with elegance wine pairing for about C$200 per person, and after tax and tip for two came out to a total around $500. Worth it? That's up for debate. We had a blast, got very full, and enjoyed some unique flavors - for more than 3 hours. Expect to spend around 4 hours here from start to finish.The elegance wine pairing lacked complexity and depth, but did showcase a nice variety. Don't feel too bad about passing up the wine pairing if budget is a concern.I'm glad we did it, but have had my fill for a time.  While it did not set the bar for flavor for me, it's the gold standard for impeccable service, and carries quite a bit of entertainment value.

An excellent fine dining institution in the heart of old Montreal.Chef Jerome Ferrer's 11 course tasting menu rivals those of many Michelin-starred restaurants, with quality food coupled with flares of ingenuity and just the right amount of ostentation.Definitely worth a visit. As far as fine dining goes, the tasting menu is a great value.

Ah-maz-ing. Completed the 12 course Chefs Tasting with Wine Paring for my birthday dinner. WOW.  We were wined and dined for the three hours, which it took to complete this meal.  Our server was amazing, attentive, and very professional. We opted for the Chefs Table overlooking the kitchen which was pretty neat. Being able to see the sous chefs, and chef Jérôme Ferrer work in the kitchen. The way the food was presented was a big show, that was a big part of it. You just need to go and experience it for yourself.  I don't have any negative comments about our experience. I will definitely dine here again next time were in Montreal.

Presentation was really the highlight of this dining experience.  The food was good but some substance was sacrificed for style.The lobster cappuccino for example was basically a shot of pretty good lobster bisque with the lobster removed and some foam on top.  I felt like I was drinking the sauce (albeit a very good one) meant for a very nice seafood dish of some kind.I just had a general sense the chef was trying too hard to create new combinations of techniques, flavors, and presentations. If I didn't have other high end dining experiences for reference, I think I would have found the dishes delicious enough, like 4-5 star good. But in actuality, with almost everything I tasted I thought he variation the chef introduced didn't add much to the dish and often detracted from a version of the dish I had somewhere else. I have complained that some high end restaurants are converging on similar recipes and presentation and I applaud Europea for trying to innovate.  But when you try to put a twist on things, you should make sure it is at least as good as the original. A lobster bisque without the lobster doesn't become magical just because you serve it like a cappuccino.  Smoked salmon served on what looked like fried wonton is tasteless if you don't warn the diner the book is filled with smoke and everything will be tasteless if you accidentally breath in the smoke. I also often thought we were served the components of a larger dish and/or the dish only had one note and needed something else on the plate.  In addition to the aforementioned lobster bisque (cappuccino), the veal cooked in clay pot was also a little odd. The presentation was good, with the waiter letting my wife break the pot before taking it back to kitchen for plating.  The civet sauce was fine, the potato slices on top were pleasantly crispy, the veal tasted good, if not extraordinarily so.  But the dish has only one flavor note nor variations on texture except for the first bite or two on the potatoes (they got soggy quick and just kind of merged into the meat and sauce).Cotton candy tree was like meh, whatever.  Meringue at the bottom of the tree was sweeter than usual and a lot sweeter than the ones in plastic bag they give out to go so I am guessing it was a slip on quality control.  The ones from the bags were spot on and I have been snacking on them since my trip to Europea.Overall, I think the place is adequate for a good date night out (especially if you haven't been to a lot of high end restaurants using modern cooking techniques) but at this price point I expect more than just adequate.

2.5 starsLikes:- Service was attentive and a lot of thought was put into delivering their dishes in unique ways.Not a fan of:- Our bill came to around $300, but there was no wow factor in the food. Not a single dish we had was memorable. Don't get me wrong, everything was cooked well, but the flavour profiles were very average.- I requested for a hot water, it was served with lemon and it came out to be $7.50 on the bill. I understand this is an upscale restaurant, but that's still a bit ridiculous.A friend ours, who used to live in Montreal recommended this restaurant to us. We decided to go with the 6 course Discovery Menu ($94.50 pp) instead of their 10 course Signature Tasting Menu ($129.50) as the foie gras and cheese plate didn't appeal to me.Prior to our order, our waitress came by and gave us a note from the chef. The personal touch was nice. Shortly after, another waitress asked if we would like "cigars" from a wooden box, which were actually fried cheese sticks. It tasted like those you would get from the freezer section in the supermarket, but again, it was a nice touch.The amuse bouches for the evening included a very thinly sliced beef jerky hung on a string, some buttery sticks, truffle oil popcorn and a fried truffle ball. I enjoyed the beef jerky a lot, from its presentation to the punch of flavour it offered. The rest of the items were just...meh. Before our first course was served, our waitress brought out a wooden box. As I opened the box, smoke was released, and a small piece of smoked salmon, with a delicious lemony cream served on what seemed like a fried wonton wrapper sat near the corner of the box.  At first, the burst of the lemon cream was delicious, but the salmon got progressively salty.Our first course was a lobster cream cappuccino with truffle puree. It was essentially a tasty lobster bisque, served in the form of a cappuccino, with no lobster meat in it. The lobster flavours were carried out very nicely and the truffle puree near the bottom was a good complement. Overall, this was a solid dish and at par with restaurants in this price range.For the second course, I went for the mushroom tart. Our waitress seared the enoki mushrooms in a sesame soy sauce in front of us on a hot cast iron plate. The thin butter puff pastry was rich and flaky and the ingredient combination worked well. The flavour profile wasn't anything special, but I did enjoy the addition of green onions which was sweet and not too pungent. My husband's dish was a big disappointment. The calamari tagliatelle sounded great on paper, but we both felt it failed on delivery. Texture wise, the calamari was cooked perfectly, and it is the first time we have had calamari served in the form of a "pasta". But the flavours were underwhelming. The quail egg and parmesan emulsion somehow got lost in the dish. We expected a bold and flavourful dish, but it ended up being bland and unexciting.Before our mains were served, we got a palate cleanser, which was a cheese ice cream with yuzu foam, mixed with small chunks of green apple and cucumber. This was very refreshing and definitely prepared our taste buds for the next course.For my main, I ordered the fish, which was cod instead of halibut for the evening. Prior to serving the dish, the waitress brought out the cod filet in a dutch oven lying on a stack of hay. They then brought it back into the kitchen for plating. The macadamia crust on the fish was quite tasty, although I wish there was more of it. Overall, the dish was executed well, but don't expect anything over the top when it comes to flavours. My husband ordered the braised veal cheeks. The waitress brought out the veal cheeks in a clay enclosure, where they asked him to hammer it open. The experience was fun, and when they brought the plated dish out again, it was a disappointment. The veal cheeks were tender, but the flavours were so mild, it was borderline bland. As for desserts, the cotton candy tree and sugary treats that came with it was cute and whimsical, but that's about it. Everything served was WAY too sweet. The only item I enjoyed was the mango vanilla pudding, which resembles the small cup desserts at AYCE Japanese buffets, except the vanilla pudding is much more creamy, and the mango puree on top is more tart. After that, we were served another dessert, which was a vanilla cream crumble, with blueberries at the bottom.Overall, there wasn't enough substance in the food as way too much thought and focus was put on the experience. If you are looking for just adequate food, and enjoy the bells and whistles added to service and presentation, then this place may work.

Europea is beautiful. Every seat is lovely and you will be happy regardless of where you are seated. The service is perfect, I mean perfect. They know everything about the menu and the wine list.The food is some of the best you will ever have. It is all made from fresh ingredients and the presentation is amazing.From start to desert you will be glad you came. Leave yourself a couple of hours to enjoy all Europea has to offer.

Wow! I cannot say enough about this restaurant! It was quite the experience!! The service was remarkable and the food presentation out of this world! Another reason to LOVE YELP! We would never have found this place without it. Upon entering the restaurant, we were led upstairs to the best table in house. A second floor window seat. Even before ordering our meal, we were presented with a few tasty treats. Jerky on a clothes line, cheddar popcorn, cheese on a stick, and bread sticks with an olive oil base. We chose the most expensive menu option. Worth every penny!  THIS IS DEFINITELY WHAT I WOULD RECOMMEND!! A dinner that consisted of about 15 courses as well as a few surprises thrown in the mix. Each course was displayed in the most creative way. From a meat cooked in a clay covering served with a hammer to break the clay or your cotton candy tree displayed like an orchid I will never forget this restaurant experience. It will certainly be one to talk about for years to come!!

I thought I reserved a table on Friday when I actually reserved Monday. But the receptionist was very generous and let us in, since there was a table with not much seating room due to a nearby table with someone in a large wheelchair. As for the food, it was not a meal -- it was a performance! I'll let the other reviews tell you all about it =D

Interesting dining experience, good service, but the food quality only worth 2 stars considering the price.They served some free starters but they were not fresh at all. The truffle popcorn tasted like it had been stored for hours, not crispy and too much truffle oil on it. The beef jerky tasted no difference than those brought from Costco. The "surprise bible" was interesting, but the salmon inside was not fresh.Surprisingly the butter came with the bread were not fresh! Tasted like it has been stored for a long time! The lobster latte tasted good, but not outstanding. The Veloute soup had a heavy taste.For main courses we had medium steak but it was not juicy. Another main course, veal in clay, tasted greasy.Cookies and macaroons in the desert were neither fresh... I was also pretty surprised to see cotton candy on the table is such an upscale restaurant.

The dining experience should be 4 stars but our waiter ruin it for us. He was uninterested, not passionate for his job and was constantly chit chatting with other staff. The overall concept of the restaurant was fun and well thought through. A truly entertaining experience drawing childhood memories back; like roasting marshmallows. My personal fav experience was the oyster catching short film before the dish, even thought the dish it self was so-so. We had the 12 course with wine pairing (regular selections).

I don't understand how this place has 4.5 stars. No offense to my fellow Yelpers; perhaps they had a different experience.I came here for lunch and got their 5 course prix fixe, which was honestly not much to write home about. I live in NYC, where we have an abundance of fine dining options; I've also dined at reputable places around the world and I love exploring the food culture in every city. I can eat cheaply and expensive and enjoy everything across the spectrum. This place was not worth it.The food: I enjoyed the lobster cappuccino and the tagliatelle, but the other dishes were subpar. Even the dishes that I enjoyed were not a 5 star dining experience; I could have enjoyed these for cheaper at other restaurants. The other food was just ok. You don't get what you pay for in terms of quantity or quality.The service was absolutely atrocious and snobby. I was greeted initially by a friendly gentleman, but the hostess/server that I had in my dining room was a complete snob. She was attending to other tables, never even gave me a glance or stopped by to see if I needed anything (which I did, several times). She attended to parties that arrived after I did, with menus, water, etc - I saw her asking them if they had any questions about the menu - took their orders before she even came to me once after dropping off a menu at some point. I don't know if it's that I was dining alone, I was the only non-Caucasian person, didn't speak French? Regardless, I felt completely snubbed. I asked for a drink prior to any of my courses, and she didn't remember. I asked her again in the middle of my first course (since she hadn't stopped by), and she made no apologies for forgetting. She finally brought it toward the end of my second course. I understand that these things can be forgotten, but what's important to me is how someone responds to issues like this.I went to Bouillon Bilk for dinner several days before, spent only a little more for three additional courses for dinner, for much better quality food and service. Europea was not a worthwhile dining experience. Would have rather had a bagel for that meal.

Dinner at Europea was a magical experience. I came with a large group of people so we ordered some appetizers to share and each ordered our own entree. Even before our appetizers were brought up, we were brought a series of amuse-bouche, such as cheese lollipops, lobster cappuccinos, smoked salmon, etc. it was fantastic and really engaging to try!For our appetizers, we ordered the foie gras, deer tartare, and the lobster salad. It was all very good, especially the deer. For my entree, I ordered the scallops and it was plated absolutely beautifully. Some of my companions ordered the lobster and homemade pasta and they also said it was incredible. The dessert round they brought us was also absolutely wonderful! You cannot go wrong with Europea. It is truly a dining exper

I had the 5-course tasting menu during lunch. Everything was beautifully presented and the juxtaposition of the flavours meshed wonderfully together. Although the food was delicious, the service was even more impressive. I had a bit of trouble with parking in the area and the staff patiently waited for me, even holding my food in the kitchen so that it stayed warm. The chef even handwrote a thank you letter to thank me for coming! I would definitely recommend Europea to anyone who wants to experience innovative fine French dining.

Rated #1 restaurant in Canada by travelers choice . Has 3 Michelin stars , I have the agree that the food is amazing , However I couldn't give them 5 stars because of the restaurant space . As I mentioned , the food is spectacular, great flavor , beautiful presentation , great experience. Great selection of wine and very friendly staff . I was surprise that there was no really a dress code . I came dressed up with a jacket , however people were on T-shirt's and some even on shorts for dinner . The room temperature was too hot . I wish they had better views outside the windows , it was just a regular street and the restrooms were closed to other dinning tables . In the men's restroom the urinals were to close to each other , no privacy . Because of space I gave 4 stars , but the quality of food and service are top 5 . Pricey but worth it

I wish I could give this place 0 stars. We walked in with no reservations, the host  told us the wait would be an hour for a guaranteed table she said we can possibly even be seated earlier. We sat at the lounge ordered drinks which I have to say we're prob the best drinks I have ever had. At 9:30 a man who was extremely rude came to us and said we can not seat you. When we told him the hostess made us a reservation for 9:30 he said no the hostess came up and started talking to us in French saying she never guaranteed anything. The man was unapologetic, did not offer us to eat at the lounge or anything he basically told us at that point to leave. Maybe they just don't welcome Americans, very disappointed at there establishment.
If i can give this disgusting place a zero, believe me i would. Keep your snotty attitude and your disgusting g ways! I'd rather spend my money in other places

We've tried restaurants in many countries, and this has to be one of the best. When we visit Montreal, we always try a new restaurant - and this is our new favorite.When you pay for a special meal while on break from life, you expect excellence. That is what you get here. Each appetizer, entree and dessert is obviously created by a great chef and artist. It's unique, always delicious and one can feel the effort that went into planning each item. The chef must be passionate about his/her work - it shows.We'll be back.

This is probably the fanciest restaurant in Montreal, and it was worth every penny. This was our splurge meal while we were in the city, so we went for the 10-course tasting menu with wine pairing. Ten courses is a lot, of course, but tasting menus are usually very small, "tasting" portions. The portions here at Europea were not always as small as typical tasting portions, but on top of that, you get way more food than the ten courses you pay for. I think they must have served us 4 amuse-bouches before the tasting menu even begun! And the final sweet dessert course was also several different items, more than just one sweet. And then -- and then! -- they even sent us home with more packaged food! Carrmelized nuts, cookies, a meringue... The whole thing was absolutely bananas. If you are looking for a special occasion meal in Montreal and are willing to spend the money on it, look no further. If you are looking to spend less, you may still order here a la carte and eat very well. Everything was spectacular. Highly recommended!

This rating is more a 3.5 than a 4. We dined with our 3 year old and booked the earliest time to make sure we wouldn't bother other diners. We ordered the tasting - Grande experience. We asked to order from the a la carte menu for our 3 year old and ended up having to pay for a mini tasting for him without our server telling us -an additional $50 and the charge of his entree. With this caliber I felt like we should have been informed that we would be forced to do that. Even though I called in before I made my reservations asking if I can order from the a la carte menu for my 3 year old. The person that answered the phone said yes however I was charged for a mini tasting for my 3 year old even though he only ate a quarter of 1 out of the 4 dishes that he got. Put that aside... in the beginning of the meal service was great as we were one of the three tables in the restaurant. However, 1 hour into the meal and the restaurant was near full that's when service started to drop. While listening in on my neighboring tables I realized they missed the water for our first course to wash our hands? - not a big deal. But then they forgot our cheese course and I had to remind them. Also, our soiled napkins a big piles of them - yes there were many because I was dining with a 3 year old were left on our table and I constantly had to ask the servers to remove and replace them.The meal also lasted 3 hours. The pace was fine in the beginning when we were the third table being served however, when the restaurant was near full that's when service slowed and we were waiting really long in between courses. Also, at the end of the meal I went downstairs before my husband and child and I didn't receive the chocolate which would have been a great touch but I was missed. Again service issues there.Don't get me wrong our servers were really nice, funny and accommodating however the hiccups above lowers their rating on service. And at this price point I do expect the service to mirror that.Finally onto the food, we did have a lot of fun and it was very interactive. However, the food didn't taste amazing. It was very good however not perfect. The last dish - healthy guilt trip - was the least memorable course and the beef course was good but again not unique or amazing. The decor of the restaurant was really nice and the washrooms were small yet decor spot on and very cozy and clean. Would I recommend this restaurant? Yes I would. However, please make sure you keep in mind there will be service issues and the food will not be perfect.
Over priced!  Food was just okay!  Main course was chicken breast very disappointed after spending hundreds of dollars.  I don't think we will com back here.

We were in Montreal for 2 nights. First night we dined at Bonaparte, it was great. Second night we dined at Europea, the food was just ok. It's not bad, but nothing to write home about. The portion for the tasting menu was tiny for the price. We ordered one bottle of wine, and it was the first time we still had half a bottle left after the main course. They tried to stuff you with cheap desserts. The wine list is terrible. High mark up for bad wine selections. I typically leave a flat amount for tips on the wine since restaurants already charge a lot for wines and I leave 17-20% tips on food. The service was ok. It's not particularly good or bad. But when we were about to leave, the waitress came to me to complain I did not give enough tips! I have dined at many high end restaurants worldwide and had never experienced such treatment. I do not think this is the kind of service one should expect from a restaurant which markets itself at this level. In my opinion, this is a shoddy "high end" restaurant for tourists who are unlikely to return.

One of the best restaurants I've ever been to. They offer sample tasting before your order arrives and it's simply delish! I had the veal cheeks that came in a clay recipient which I had to break with the hammer. The meat was so tender it melted in my mouth. The chef is truly amazing and the service was great. This restaurant will always be on my list when I visit Montreal from now

Probably the most fancy and most definitely extra restaurant I've been to in Montreal. The service here is not like any other fine dining restaurant. We first heard about this restaurant from friends who came here to try the dessert. The cotton candy tree dessert (called "passport to something") is the reason we came; but the amazing appetizers and service was why we stayed. Right after taking our order, a wonderful array of appetizers was presented to us, each in a unique and memorable way. For example, the tartar was delivered to us in a book filled with smoke, while the cheesesticks were delivered to us as cuban cigars. Each dish was beautifully made and incredibly delicious. Paired with a great wine and cheese selection, Europea soon became one of my favourite places to go to celebrate a special occasion. When my friend left Montreal, she even said that she would come back here one day, just for dinner one more time!

We didn't opt for the tasting menu but we're so full from just everything else. Here is the summary of our EPIC meal - amuse bouche: beef jerked, truffle popcorn, goat cheese lollipop, "cigar" fried mozzarella stick served on a cigar box, squid ink risotto with truffle (SOOOOO good), lobster "Cappuccino" with truffle (BEST lobster soup ever), three fresh butter, salmon with tomato served in a smoked open book, veal in a clay - Quebec veal cheeks slowly braised and cooked in clay with crispy potatoes served with Jerusalem artichokes sauce, royal lobster - lobster with butter, with homemade tagliatelle served with Vermouth cream and lemon zest and fresh truffle and foie gras, and the epic dessert with cotton candy, chocolate Nutella lollipop with pop rocks, orange cake, pancetta and petit four!

Wow! I went with a baby so it wasn't like I had a lot of time to think about eating. But the food was stunning. And despite Montreal's French bakery credentials, the brioche they brought out was the best bread I had in Montreal.

The new location is lovely!! But it seems to come at the cost of no longer having all those little surprises/palate cleansers that used to be complimentary with the meal. (They still do bread, and two amuse-bouches at the outset). Unfortunately, without all those palate cleansers, this is no longer an exceptional experience and this is like any other dinner establishment. (Note we only did the 3 course for $60pp meals so I can't comment on the 8 or 11 courses).
Must try if you come this way to Montreal. Great food and atmosphere. Set menu and tasting menu if you prefer the 3 hour dinner. Few pictures for you to decide on your own.
We enjoy our every bite. Very unique and creative! Great dinner, great staff, fantastic service. 5stars!!

It's hard to believe that the Michelin Guide refuses to consider restaurants in Canada. Europea is quite simply one of the finest restaurants in the world, and the dining experience is worthy of every type of acclaim. I really wanted to splurge for a dinner and when I booked a trip to Montreal, the first thing I did was make a reservation for Europea (you'll need a reservation made more than a month in advance, and if you don't show up to your booking, you'll incur a $200 charge). The style of the restaurant is fine dining, with a French-Italian focus. The dress code is "business casual," but men should wear at least a jacket or tie (preferably both). When you arrive, you'll be received into a handsome dining room, with immaculate and bilingual staff ready to attend to any desire. There was a personal note from the chef waiting at my table. I had the 8 course exploration menu, with wine pairings chosen by a sommelier. They started with an amuse-bouche of dried meat, goat cheese and maple smoked salmon lox. The subsequent courses were simply perfect, each one was served with an expertly chosen wine and the waitstaff attentively refilled my wine glass before it was even half empty. The presentation of the dishes was also impressive. The cappuccino lobster bisque changed my life, and the veal carpaccio was ten times better than anything I've had in Italy. The menu provides an excellent fois gras and handmade pasta with quail egg and caviar. The main seafood dish was fresh halibut and the main meat dish was clay-baked veal cheek, and the tasting menu gave me an opportunity to taste both. The meal concluded with a cheese course and assorted bonbons. The total bill was about $200 per person, but I would gladly pay twice that for the Europea experience.

If someone else raves about this place, then tells you they will pay for your meal here, you may regard it more highly.Aside from finding bits of lobster shell all in my lobster dish (and having this met with a shrug from my server), most of the food was good.The challenge here is that it is just good. For a premium price, the menu, service, and restaurant seems 2002. Nothing stands out, though everything seems familiar enough and increasingly better with wine.There are many places I enjoy when I visit Montreal. This is not one I would want to visit again. There are equally expensive options with better food, service, and experience.

Oh my! So we did the 6 courses testing menu, it's about $90 and yes it worth every penny. Staff was really nice, the food was AMAZING!! I mean I can keep in typing about how delicious my meal was and how my husband thanks me for 100 times that I found this place. Book it and try it. You won't be disappointed. Oh wear loose cloth is a must!!

I have been this restaurant this summer with four of my friends, and we all tried its signatured tasting menu. When walking into the place, the warm and sweet interior dining environment plus the Zen feeling table decoration created a delight dining atmosphere. However, the table decoration might occupy a lot of the table space that plates had to be placed very closely.I believe the tasting menu included around 3 appetizers, 5 main dishes, and 2 deserts. Surprisingly, we got 3 small snacks before we formally started, and 2 more desserts afterwards as easter egg. All the dishes were in great looking and showed ingenuity that we wanted to photograph every detail. But when it comes to the taste, I would say that I was a little bit disappointed. I expected more layers of flavors, and more connections bewteen different food ingredients, but I felt flat. And some ingredients did not match to each other in one dish. The service was really good and sweet. Some servers speak French, which I do not quite understand.Overall, my dining experience was good in this place, but I would think it over whether I want to come back, considering its price.

We went to Toque last night and thought its tasting menu was very good. Tonight's 10 course tasting menu dinner at Europea was absolutely far better than Toque's! I would say that this is one of the best restaurants that we have ever been to!

If I had a chance to put 10 stars I would. Best experience of my life with my husband and kids. The food is art and out of this world. It is delicious and it looks picture perfect. It is one of the places to visit (eat) before you die. Thank you to our waiter and rest of the staff for awesome service and delicious food. We love it and we will definitely come back here if we visit Montréal.

God, this is such a great place,We went there in November as part of the Montreal à table event, where you get to taste specialty restaurants food for a set price. We thought it might not be as good as the real thing since they would likely be full. But Europea Jerome Ferrer's restaurant remains a finest gourmet rendez-vous even when there is a lot of people.Incredible food, great service, overall fabulous experience, you MUST try it :)

The pictures already posted are probably better than the ones I took. We got the 12 service for 4 people and wow, it was a whole production. Absolutely incredible. Even the utensils were impressive! The service was amazing and the food was an EXPERIENCE. Highly, highly recommend this place.

I'm still not sure why it's taken me so long to write a review about the best meal I've ever had. Back when my husband and I were living in NYC, we decided for his Birthday in May 2015, we'd drive to Montreal. It's about a 6 hour drive, 9 if you bring your Beagle with you because you want him to have international status. I made the reservation a couple weeks in advance noting that come he'll or high water, we were going to do the Tasting Menu. And I am so glad we did. Here's why:Firstly, they take you thru a journey. I always thought when people said that, it was cheesy, but the only think cheesy about this restaurant was the cheese cigars and the goat cheese truffle. The waiter really takes you thru the courses (of which I lost count after 9 including palette cleansers and amouse bouche plates). Here's an example:Waiter (holding what appears to be a book): "would you care for some light reading?"Me: "ok!"Waiter sets down book: "please now open your book."I open said book to a plume of smoke from the burning apple wood in the book and a goat cheese truffle drizzled in squid ink (I think?). Either way, explosions in my mouth.Oh! And:Waiter: "would you care for a cigar?"Me: "um.... a cigar?"Waiter opens a humidor: "a cheese cigar." Presenting a Camembert Fried cheese stick. I'm not doing the food justice as it was such an incredible night of flavor and presentation. I never thought having dinner could be so much fun, but Europea has become my favorite restaurant. I live in Napa now, so it's not easy to go to dinner there even on a weekend trip to Montreal, but it's on the list of next trips and I guarantee you, Europea will be the main event.Takeaways from this review:Best restaurant everCheese cigarsLight reading

This one is going to be long.......just warning you. So this was the 1st time I've ever been to a restaurant that provides the tasting menu options, either $89.50/person for the 6 course or $119.50/person for the 12 course. Either way, you're getting a large variety of dishes to quench your palate. The way it's explained, the 12 course option has dishes 1/2 the size of the 6 so you get the same amount of food, however, in between they bring little amuse bouches so it's definitely more food. The service is what you'd expect from a restaurant of this caliber, very attentive and helpful. I will say that my experience in many Montreal restaurants lead me to believe service is not in their vocabulary but Europea was truly an exception. We had 13 people at our table, some a little more demanding with their food...."less sauce, no sauce, this or that on the side", etc. No problem, they accommodated everything. For the vegetarians there is a separate tasting menu and they even allowed to pick and choose some items from the vegetarian and some from the regular. Each dish is carefully placed and then explained to the group in perfect detail.The food was outstanding! We all had the 6 course meal. They start with a variety of amuse-bouches such as peppered jerky, cheese lollipops, assorted butters and breads, flavored popcorn and more. Then to prepare you for the amazing meal to come, their signature lobster bisque cappuccino arrives.......holy crap! It's worth going to Europea just for that.  You then get to choose one of 3 appetizers and one of 3 main course. The portions are quite large. My ricotta ravioli with sauteed mushroom, truffle sauce and pan-seared foie gras was to die for, fortunately it didn't come to that. The breads are all freshly baked and amazing, I did not need to have 3 pieces of the french baguette but I never let that stop me. They also do some very unique dishes.....one amuse-bouche is a box that looks like a book. You open the book and out comes this amazing smokey smell like logs in a fire and it reveals a tiny but delicious salmon in a small cup, I forget what else was it it but it was really good. Then comes dessert, also a barrage of little dishes that includes sorbet, cotton candy tree, panna cotta, a variety of macaroons and cookies, caramel and nut cheesecake lollipops, nuts, coconut marshmallow squares and more. I will admit I was surprised by the quantity of food. I'm not a small eater and fully expected to have alot of small dishes and to leave hungry.....boy was I wrong, I left stuffed. Europea is worth the visit, however be prepared for a long night. It's not because the service is slow, it's because the food just keeps coming and you can't wait to see what they bring next. Not the place to go if you need to catch a movie. However, if you want a really nice restaurant with great food and that allows you to spend time with the person or people you're with, this is the perfect choice.

This was an amazing dining experience from start to finish.  The presentation was incredible. The calamari tagliatelle was so soft and tender, the halibut was perfect, the desserts were all incredible.  Do yourself a favor and try this place. You won't regret it.

This was definitely a memorable experience. Each course was layered, thoughtful, yet playful and didn't take itself too seriously.  It's a wonderful fine dining experience and I'd love to go back if in town again. I loved each course and the service was impeccable. It is definitely worth the time and $$. For the price you get an extremely elevated and unique experience. I've definitely paid more for worse meals. You will want to make a reservation in advance.

Lovely ambiance, decadent food w/wonderful wine pairings! I am not a native French speaker and the servers were just as attentive, incredibly accommodating and just lovely throughout all six(plus) courses. Sasha was especially warm w/great personality and humor while remaining very professional. THE FOOD WAS AMAZING! I'd love to share the Chef's surprises but would never want to ruin the surprise for others! More than an amazing meal, it's a culinary experience.
